MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Advance Factory Buildings.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to help the IDA to provide much needed advance factory buildings; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that there is a shortage of buildings suitable for new industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: A significant State investment in industrial property is being undertaken as part of the EC supported Operational Programme for Industrial Development 1989-1993. In 1990 the IDA will spend £17 million on their building operations activities while a further £6 million will be spent by SFADCo in those areas coming within their remit. This represents in total an increase in expenditure over 1989 of £2.4 million.

MainHeading.P: Between the two agencies there is almost three and a half million square feet of vacant space nationally. In addition, private sector developers have agreed with the IDA to provide 500,000 square feet of space with a further 160,000 square feet under negotiation. While certain towns may not have an advance factory immediately available I cannot accept in the circumstances that there is a shortage of space nationally for new industry. I might add that in order to encourage the provision of advance factories in areas which might be less attractive to commercial developers the 1990 Finance Act extends the availability of the business expansion scheme to the construction and leasing of advance factories by local community groups.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Exchange Rate.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: the action he will take to ensure that the benefits resulting from a strong exchange rate are fully passed on to consumers in the form of lower prices; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Qst.Quest: the additional measures he intends taking to ensure that the benefits of a strong punt are reflected in reduced prices to consumers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 28 and 140 together.

Consequent on the decision by the Government in 1986 to disband the National Prices Commission, the Deputies will be particularly aware that, with the exception of certain petroleum products, detailed statutory price control is no longer operated. I feel sure the Deputies will agree that statutory price control is not, for a variety of reasons, an ideal instrument for tackling problems which inherently emanate from the shortcomings, to one extent or another, of competition legislation. The policy of the Government is to maintain the emphasis on creating and ensuring an improved competitive environment. To this end, I intend to introduce a new competition Bill this year. This Bill will bring about conditions which will enable market forces to promote greater efficiency and to pass on the benefits to the consumer. This legislation will give effect, in domestic law, to provisions similar to Articles 85 and 86 of the Treaty of Rome. Anti-competitive agreements, decisions or concerted practices between undertakings trading in the State and abuses of a dominant position in the market will be prohibited.

MainHeading.P: I continue to be concerned that the consumer should benefit from the increased purchasing power of the IR£. The House will be aware that I have already taken action where specific circumstances seemed to warrant this. For example, the attention of distributors in the food sector was drawn to the apparent disparity between the selling price of their imported food products and the UK selling price. Subsequently a range of price decreases were implemented by a variety of suppliers.

Ongoing selective monitoring of prices by the Department has resulted in particular distributors being requested to supply appropriate data where downward price movements have not been apparent.In this regard, Deputies will be aware that the prices of imported UK magazines have come down significantly in the last month.

The House has, I am sure, noted with satisfaction the latest official figures for the consumer price index indicating that the annual rate of inflation has fallen from 4.2 per cent in mid-February to 3.5 per cent in mid-May, maintaining the downward trend evident since early this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Concentration of Economic Activities.

Qst.Quest: if he will elaborate on his view, expressed recently, that the forces for the geographical concentration of economic activities in a more integrated Community market will be a good deal stronger than the forces of diffusion; if he will outline the implications of that view for Ireland in the future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I expressed the view which the Deputy has noted at the Conference on Regional Policies in the European Single Market held by the Commission of the European Community's Council of Ministers, at Dublin Castle on 11 June last. A detailed elaboration of my views is set out in the address which I delivered at the official opening of the conference — a copy of which I am making available to the Deputy and placing in the Library of the House.

MainHeading.P: I raised the issue of the concentration of economic activities in the more developed parts of the Community in the context of the arguments I put forward to support the need for more comprehensive Community regional policies as an inherent part of the movement towards a European Single Market and beyond that towards, perhaps, Economic and Monetary Union. I made the point, in particular, in relation to the need for the continued allocation of increased and substantial resources by the Community to regional policies beyond 1993 — the end-date to which increased Structural Fund allocations have so far been agreed.

I pointed out in my address that, in the absence of countervailing regional policies, the result of the forces for the geographical concentration of economic activities as opposed to the forces for diffusion in a more integrated Community market would be to increase regional disparities across the Community.Such an outcome would not be favourable for Ireland. Community regional policies, which have recently been strengthened in the context of the Single European Act, are designed to prevent such an imbalance in regional development across the Community. Ireland is benefiting significantly from the additional resources being made available under these policies to support enterprises in areas such as industry and tourism and to provide the basic infrastructure required for developmental purposes in areas such as transport, research and technological developoment, education and training and so on.

A further point I made in my address is that while the recent strengthening of Community regional policies is a positive step in the right direction this must be seen as a beginning and not an end. There is a need for the further development of regional policies and their integration with other Community policies in areas such as competition, including State aids, research and development, training and transport regulation and deregulation.

Qst.Quest: if he will initiate a review of the Consumer Information Act, 1978, having regard to the distortion of emblems being used in the marketing of dairy produce; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I am assuming that the Deputy's concern relates to the use of emblems in the presentation of dairy products or substitutes.

The designation used in the marketing of milk and milk products are protected under EC Council Regulation No. 1898/87 of 2 July 1987 (O. J. No. L 182 of 3.7.87, page 36). In addition it is an offence under the Consumer Information Act 1978 to make any false or misleading claims in relation to any goods in the course of a business, trade or profession.
In the circumstances I do not consider it necessary to initiate a review of the Consumer Information Act 1978 as suggested by the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Labelling of Foodstuffs.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the measures he has at his disposal in order to compel food manufacturers to identify product ingredients as part of the labelling and presentation of products, particularly in relation to the dairy industry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The information given on the labels of foodstuffs is governed by the European Communities (Labelling, Presentation and Advertising of Foodstuffs) Regulations, 1982 (S.I. No. 205 of 1982). These Regulations, which gave effect to an EC Directive, require that specified details including a list of ingredients, be given on foodstuffs generally. Some foodstuffs, including certain dairy produce, are exempt from the requirement to show a list of ingredients.
Failure to give any of the details required is an offence.

MainHeading.P: Enforcement of these Regulations and any decision to prosecute for non-compliance are the responsibility of the director of consumer affairs and fair trade who is independent in the performance of his duties, or the health boards.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Administrative Burden on Business.

Qst.Quest: in light of his admission in April 1989, of the need for a deregulation structure to reduce the amount of red tape which confronts small businesses, the efforts which he has made in the intervening period to deal with a situation where, according to the Small Firms Association, an average company is faced with 150,000 questions to complete per annum; and if he will outline his plans in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The industrial costs monitoring group which operates under the aegis of my Department and which includes representation from the business sector has undertaken an analysis of the administrative burden imposed on business firms by official requirements. The analysis was undertaken in close consultation with business representative bodies including the Confederation of Irish Industry, the Federation of Irish Employers and the Construction Industry Federation. Arising from this analysis a number of actions have been identified which would help to reduce the administrative burden on business. These have been drawn to the attention of relevant Government Departments and State agencies and changes have been and are being introduced to improve the position in the light of the information provided.

I will continue to impress on my colleagues in Government, Government Departments and State Agencies the need to reduce to the minimum necessary the administrative burden placed on business by official sources.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Trade Balance.

Qst.Quest: the ten countries both within and outside the EC whose trade balance with this country is least favourable from this country's point of view; the way in which this imbalance might be redressed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I propose to circulate in the Official Report a tabular statement giving details of the countries both within and outside the EC with which Ireland has the largest trade deficit. This table also shows, for each county, the deficit as a proportion of total trade.
Within the EC, Ireland has unfavourable trade balances with only two countries — the UK and Portugal.

In 1989 the deficit with the UK was £131 million but this figure represented only 1 per cent of a total trade of nearly £10 billion with what is still our largest trading partner. Furthermore, the deficit has reduced from £815 million in 1985.

Exporters to the UK have at their disposal the full range of CTT services. For example, the UK is one of the countries targeted by CTT in its Source Ireland Programme. This programme is designed to raise awareness among British industrial buyers of Ireland as a source of industrial products. The electronics, engineering and processing sectors in particular are being targeted. In addition, CTT continues to arrange successful buyer airlifts from the UK which bring key buyers and agents into contact with Irish exporters. In 1990, an introductory programme for potential Irish suppliers to the UK Home Shopping Market, which is worth £6 billion, was launched. In 1989, Irish exports to the UK increased by 12 per cent.

As regards Portugal, our trade deficit has been decreasing since 1985 when it was almost £20 million. Last year, our trade with Portugal was almost in balance with a small deficit of only £5 million. Our trade with Portugal is small but growing with exports last year showing a significant increase of 36 per cent. This figure indicates an increasing awareness among Irish exporters of Portugal as an export market. Last year, 25 companies were assisted to enter the Portuguese market through CTT's trade correspondent in Lisbon. An information stand was organised at Portugal's most important agricultural trade fair. In addition, an inward buyer airlift and a trade mission of potential Irish exporters were also organised by CTT this year.
Outside, the EC, the USA and Japan are the two countries with which we have the biggest trade imbalance. Last year, our imbalance with the US was £817 million and with Japan was £402 million.

MainHeading.P: The deficit with the US is largely attributable to the high imports of US raw materials and semi-finished goods by US subsidies in Ireland. In the US market, where exports increased by 17 per cent last year, CTT has drafted a five year plan to enable Irish exports to increase by 15 per cent each year despite expected tougher marketing conditions. The main focus will be on subsectors within the engineering, electronics and consumer product, including food, areas and will be targeted at the North Eastern region of the US.

The largest imports from Japan consist of cars and electronic products. As regards efforts to reduce the trade imbalance with Japan, these are showing good results with Irish exports up 33 per cent last year. The recent import liberalisation programme introduced by the Japanese Government should open new opportunities for Irish companies. CTT will be arranging another general trade mission as well as group promotions for promising sectors for 1990. Following the Taoiseach's visit to Japan in April 1989, a committee was established between my Department and the Ministry for International Trade and Industry in Japan to strengthen trade and economic links between the two countries and this committee meets on a regular basis to ensure that institutional or operational constraints on trade are kept to a minimum.

Ireland's trade imbalances with Taiwan, China and Hong Kong arise because of consumer goods imports. Small trade imbalances also arise from Irish imports of raw materials and basic consumer goods from other countries. Examples are Polish and Colombian coal, Finnish paper, Brazilian animal feed and wool and clothing from Turkey. Nevertheless, Irish exports to a number of these countries showed a strong performance and in 1989 our exports increased as follows, Brazil, up 74 per cent; Finland, up 20 per cent; Turkey, up 13 per cent; Poland, up 8 per cent and Hong Kong, up 5 per cent.

In all countries where we have trade imbalances, CTT continues to promote Irish exports through its full range of exporter services e.g. targeted marketing consultancy, market information and research, design and product development, trade missions and group promotions.

In overall trade terms, Ireland's performance in 1989 was very satisfactory. Exports by Irish companies reached £14.6 billion. There was a trade surplus of £2.3 billion and this was achieved despite an increase of 20 per cent in imports.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EC Jobs Industrial Policy.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: the steps he has taken or plans to take, during Ireland's Presidency of the EC, to promote the concept of a common jobs-industrial policy for the EC; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The whole thrust of my Presidency role in the Internal Market, Industry, Trade and Research Councils has been to seek to create the basis for sustained industrial development and job creation throughout the Community.

MainHeading.P: In my capacity as President of the Industry Council I have sought to promote policy initiatives particularly in relation to high technology industries as well as initiatives to help small and medium sized enterprises to participate more fully in Community programmes which support industrial development such as access to public procurement and R&D.
Industrial policies on a Community wide basis have already been developed and applied in areas such as coal and steel, textiles and shipbuilding.
Many other Community policies also impact directly on jobs and industry. These include competition policy, macroeconomic policy, international trade policy, R&D, and the Internal Market programme.

All of these aspects are being brought together in a working paper on industrial policy prepared by the Commission which is designed to establish the principles and framework of future EC Industrial Policy. Discussion by the member states on this document commenced recently and I would expect conclusions to be reached from it within a short time.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ireland's Position in International Marketplace.

Qst.Quest: his views on whether Ireland has a poor competitive position in the international marketplace; if the Government has any plans to improve that position; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: In my view, the competitive position of Irish industry in the international marketplace has not been better for many years and is continuing to improve.

This improvement is reflected in our success on world markets where our exports have risen from £10.7 billion in 1987 to £14.6 billion in 1989. This represents an increase of 36 per cent and is a magnificent performance by any standards.

Our success in breaking out of the previously damaging spiral of rising costs and lost competitiveness is due in a large measure to the Government's resolute handling of the national finances and the co-operation of the social partners in implementing the terms of the Programme for National Recovery.

The effect of these measures has been to create a new economic climate conducive to growth and export development.Inflation has been reduced to a point where, at 3.5 per cent, we are now below the EC average and well below the rate in the UK our biggest single trading partner. Interest rates are also well below those in the UK and expected to moderate further. Our unit wage costs have moderated significantly and the cost of public utilities such as electricity, telecommunications and post have either been held at 1987 levels or have been reduced.
The combined impact of progress on all these fronts has been to restore a new level of competitiveness to Irish industry and industry has responded positively as our export figures illustrate.

MainHeading.P: Of course, success in the international marketplace will not be achieved solely on the basis of cost efficiency. The modern market requires quality products, efficient delivery and overall marketing professionalism. Under the National Programme for Industrial Development 1989-1993, which is being supported by EC Structural Funds, the Government has put in place a comprehensive range of measures to support Irish industry in achieving new levels of performance in the international marketplace.

Given the Government's firm commitment to maintaining and building on the progress achieved to date, I have every confidence that Irish industry is now positioned to achieve even greater success in the international marketplace in the future.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to alter the structure of areas of responsibility of the various State agencies involved in job creation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley

Qst.Quest: if he is considering implementing a price control mechanism on coal, taking into account the fact that in Drogheda, County Louth coal is £7 per bag, in Dublin it is £6.50 per 50 kg bag, smokeless coal is £7 per 40 kg in Drogheda and in Dublin Coalite is £10 per 35 kg bag; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the Minister for Industry and Commerce when the report of the Fair Trade Commission on petrol distribution will be published; the reason for the delay in publishing this report; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.Quest: if Ireland is a member of or a party to the international group known as the Co-ordinating Committee on Exports COCOM; if it follows the COCOM list of products which may not be exported to certain countries; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)

Qst.Quest: if he will, in consultation with the National Archives, ensure that his Department maintains clear and comprehensive records of the current administration of Government business so that in time the transfer of such records to the National Archives will enable future generations to obtain an accurate and informed picture of the business of Government; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: It has always been the practice of the Department of the Taoiseach to maintain clear and comprehensive records of the administration of Government business for transfer in due course to the National Archives in accordance with statutory requirements.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the archival records, contained within his Department, which have been transferred to the National Archives; the records retained and the reason for their retention; if he will further indicate when those records not specifically retained will be transferred to the National Archives; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: The following records of my Department have been available for public inspection in the National Archives for some years: (a) Government minutes, 1922-54; (b) registered files mentioned in the Government minutes, 1922-54; (c) registered files specifically requested by researchers, 1922-60.

In the course of 1990, my Department have transferred in excess of 8,600 files, i.e. almost all of the remaining registered files for the period 1922-60 to the National Archives. A further batch of registered files, numbering under 800 and also for the period 1922-60, remain to be examined. It is expected that many of those files will be transferred to the National Archives before the end of this year. A number may be retained by my Department on one or more of the grounds specified in section 8 (4) of the National Archives Act, 1986. It is not possible at this stage to estimate the number of files which may be so retained.

I hope to visit the National Archives later this year to formally release the Government minutes for the period 1954-60 as well as the files transferred recently. I know that all persons with an interest in modern Irish history will greatly welcome the granting of public access to that material.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the sections of the National Museum which are not open to public view at present and the reasons; and whether there are plans to extend services in the National Museum for the summer peak of foreign visits and for the Dublin Cultural Capital Year.

Speaker.P: There are some sections of the National Museum closed at present due to the refurbishment works in progress. These include the Furniture, Chinese, Historical and Egyptian galleries.They will reopen when the refurbishment is completed. The Ceramics Room, Music Room, Textile Room and 1916 Room have been refurbished and will reopen shortly when the additional attendants being recruited have taken up duty. The upstairs sections of the Natural History Museum are temporarily closed due to staff shortages and rostering requirements, but these will be reopened shortly. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Third Lomé III Convention.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: the reason only 20 per cent of allocated resources were spent under Lomé III; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: While only some 30 per cent of the overall amount of the Community's financial assistance provided under the Third Lomé Convention has so far been disbursed, the full amount of these resources will be disbursed over the next few years. In fact expenditure of some 80 per cent of the funds has already been approved.

Most of the Lomé resources are given in the form of programme and project aid. This involves first of all the establishment, with the close co-operation of each ACP State, of an indicative programme for each country. Subsequently programme aid is approved in stages. Individual projects are then identified and elaborated, and the appropriate aid committed. Only as individual projects are implemented is the aid disbursed. To a large extent, the slow rate of disbursement is due to the high priority accorded to rural development programmes under Lomé III. These programmes involve a highly complex mix of agricultural, social and infrastructural developments which can only be implemented over a number of years.

The pattern of approval, commitment and disbursement is generally similar to that under previous Lomé Conventions. The Community and the ACP States have, however, agreed to examine how this process could be speeded up. An endeavour is being made under Lomé IV to get the programming process under way more speedily.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Nuclear Submarines.

Qst.Quest: if his Department have received any communication, in the past ten years, from the captain of any nuclear submarine whose intention it was to pass through Irish territorial waters by surface travel; if he has satisfied himself that the necessary regulation has been adhered to during this period; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: Under the provisions of international law all vessels have a right of innocent passage through the territorial waters of another State provided that, in the case of submarines, they travel on the surface and fly their flags for identification.Specific authorisation to exercise this right of innocent passage, or notification that it has been exercised, is not required. Therefore, we have no record of any country notifying the Irish authorities of the innocent passage of nuclear submarines through Irish territorial waters.

There is one incident on record in which an Irish Naval vessel in exercise of its normal surveillance activities on 14 April 1989, observed a submarine travelling on the surface while in Irish territorial waters. The submarine was not flying its flag. The Irish patrol vessel approached the submarine and asked that a flag be hoisted. The request was complied with. The vessel was a submarine of the United States Navy. This incident was brought to the attention of the United States authorities who were reminded of their obligation to fly a flag while in territorial waters. In response, the Government were assured that this incident was exceptional and that it is normal practice for United States submarines to comply with this requirement of international law regarding innocent passage. The Government have no record of any other incidents of this nature.

MainHeading.P: We are very seriously concerned about the dangers that submarines pose to shipping and about the nuclear hazard in the event of an accident involving nuclear powered or armed submarines. We avail of every opportunity in international fora, such as the United Nations and the International Maritime Organisation, to focus attention on the specific problem. We will continue to raise specific incidents with the authorities of the countries concerned as the need arises.

Qst.Quest: if Ireland has made representations to the Governments of Japan and Norway protesting at their disregard of the Moratorium on Commercial Whaling which was agreed in 1986; and if the Government will make any representations to these Governments to persuade them to cease whaling.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: We have not made specific representations to the countries concerned on the matter raised.

Ireland has, since becoming a party to the International Convention on the Regulation of Whaling in 1985, taken a decidedly pro-conservation position within the International Whaling Commission.The commission administers the convention and is responsible for the international ban on whaling which has been in force since 1986. The whaling ban is due to be discussed at the 42nd annual meeting of the commission to be held in Noordwijk, The Netherlands on 2-6 July. The Irish representative at that meeting will continue to follow the strong pro-conservation line to which we are committed.
Our support within the commission for the international ban confirms our opposition to whaling and, in these circumstances, I would see no need to make bilateral representations on the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Central Bank Report.

Qst.Quest: his views on the recent Central Bank report regarding pay policy, low inflation and the Programme for National Recovery.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. A. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy refers to the annual report of the Central Bank, published in May. I fully concur with the Central Bank's views on the importance of competitiveness. Improved competitiveness is a vital catalyst for increased growth and employment. This is evident from the growth and employment performance during the Programme for National Recovery. The annual growth rate of GNP over the life of the programme is expected to be 3½ per cent, and non-agricultural employment is expected to increase by 16,000 on average this year, following on an increase of 13,000 in 1989. We can aspire to continue on this path of progress only if we remain competitive, especially in the challenging context of closer European integration.

Pay moderation, in particular, is essential if the virtuous circle of improved competitiveness and increased growth, referred to in the Central Bank report, is to be sustained. Realism in pay settlements has been a feature of the Programme for National Recovery and must be central in any follow-on arrangement. As the record of the programme shows, pay moderation can be fully compatible with improvement in workers' living standards.The combination of moderate pay increases, low inflation, and the taxation relief which has been possible in the past two years and into 1990, means that the real take-home pay of workers with average industrial earnings will have increased by 4 per cent to 8½ per cent over the three years of the programme. This compares with a fall in purchasing power of 7 per cent to 11 per cent over the period 1980 to 1987, when money incomes grew far more rapidly.

MainHeading.P: Inflation is on a downward trend since November of last year. The benefits of our strong exchange rate, and the reductions in VAT and excise duties which I announced in the budget, were in evidence in the Consumer Price Index for Mid-May. This showed a year-on-year increase of 3.5 per cent compared with an increase of 4.2 per cent for mid-February.The inflation rate should decline further in the remainder of the year. It is expected that the year-on-year increase in prices will have fallen to around 2½ per cent by year-end. As I stated in my budget speech, there must be unrelenting action to control inflation and costs of all kinds. My views on this are consistent with those expressed in the Central Bank report.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the details of any tests or experiments that prove positively and conclusively that BSE, or mad cow disease, can never be transmissible to humans; if no such tests exist, if he will reconsider banning British beef imports or require that the national origins of beef be labelled at retail level; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: It has been confirmed at the level of highest scientific knowledge that BSE is not considered a risk to public health.

On 7 June 1990, the Council of Ministers of Agriculture at an emergency meeting convened by me agreed on a series of control measures in relation to beef exported from the UK to other member states. These supplemented existing EC rules and afford additional guarantees as to the safety of such meat. Community legislation also provides that beef or packages of beef exported from one member state to another must bear a health mark. This includes the initials of the country of consignment and the number of the export approved plant. The export must also be accompanied by an EC health certificate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: I am pressing the EC for the earliest possible approval of the submission for the extension and reclassification of Ireland's disadvantaged areas. The inclusion of additional new areas in the Community list of less favoured areas requires a Commission proposal to the Council of Ministers and agreement by a qualified majority of Council while proposals for reclassifying existing areas require approval at Commission level. Approval by the European Parliament is, of course, also required.

The approval and implementation of the comprehensive proposals included in our submission is therefore dependent on the completion of the above procedures but I expect that the necessary procedural steps will be completed during 1990.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that a person (details supplied) in County Sligo was not paid suckler cow grants for two of his cows; and if, in the special circumstances surrounding this case, the extra money will be paid.

if his attention has been drawn to a change in the rules in 1989 whereby suckler cow grants are no longer given for reactor cows if the reactors have been removed at the request of the veterinary inspectors and ERAD, even for the shortest of times before the filling in of the application for the grants; and if he will make a statement on the unfairness of this and the negative input it has for getting the fullest possible co-operation from farmers for the removal of reactor animals.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 125 and 126 together.

MainHeading.P: It is a requirement laid down by the EC and binding on member states since the inception of the suckler cow premium scheme that an applicant may receive premium only on those suckler cows which he/she has on his/her holding at the date of application. As payment of suckler cow premium can be made on reactor suckler cows removed after lodgement of applications but before the expiry of the six months retention period under the scheme, this EC rule of ten years' standing concerning reactors removed before application does not seem unfair to me.

In the case of the County Sligo herdowner, the two cows mentioned were removed for slaughter from the herd five days before the person named completed his application. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Small Farmer Population.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the continuing decline in the number of small farmers, which is having a severe impact on rural population and on the social fabric of rural Ireland, with its effect on school and church attendances and on the viability of voluntary and sporting organisations, he will outline the steps he proposes to take, in consultation with the EC, to provide for an improved standard of living for these farmers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: There has undoubtedly been a decline in the number of small farmers over the years in Ireland, as in every other developed country. There has also been a growing trend towards part-time farming. The EC Farm Structures Survey of 1985 estimated that the holder/manager of one-third of holdings had a gainful activity other than farming. The more recently published Household Budget Survey for 1987 also indicates that many farm households have income sources other than those derived from farming. This survey showed that, on average, farming represented only 54 per cent of gross farm household income. For small farmers, the contribution of farming to total household income is considerably less.

MainHeading.P: Thus, measures which seek to stem migration from rural Ireland and protect the social fabric must have a broad focus, covering both agricultural and rural development policies.

I have at all times, in Community negotiations, sought to ensure that the fundamental mechanisms of the CAP are kept fully in place in order to ensure that the basic supports necessary to underpin a successful agri-food industry are in place. To maintain viable rural economics in certain areas there is, of course, a need to supplement traditional agriculture by certain income aids, non-traditional farming and indeed non-agricultural activities. In this context I have sought through a number of measures to ensure that the sector can make a maximum contribution to rural employment.

The Community Support Framework adopted under the expanded EC structural funds provides for assistance of close to £3 billion for Ireland over the period 1989-1993. It contains a number of measures which will help to sustain employment levels in the agricultural and rural economy and provides additional resources for on-farm investment, an increase in headage payments, diversification of production and for investment in rural tourism. The Government's proposal for the extension and reclassification of Ireland's disadvantaged areas will, when approved by the Community, be particularly helpful in this regard. The abolition this year of the off farm income criterion under the disadvantaged area scheme is, of course, also extremely beneficial to many farm families in these areas.

The operational programme for rural development, currently being submitted to Brussels includes a scheme of aid for alternative farm enterprises, a national agri tourism scheme and forestry measures, all of which will give an important boost to job creation in rural areas in the next few years.

Furthermore, the experience gained from the operation of the Integrated Rural Development Pilot Programme, due to conclude in October 1990, will be built upon to launch initiatives on a wider scale which will assist in the provision of jobs and wealth creation in rural Ireland. I would hope that the recently signalled Community initiative on rural development will be helpful in that regard.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Casual Trading.

Qst.Quest: if he will amend the Casual Trading Act, 1980, in view of the difficulties being experienced by local authorities arising from indiscriminate casual trading around the country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The Casual Trading Act, 1980, was deliberately framed to give local authorities the power to regulate and control casual trading in their own functional areas. Casual trading is not a national problem but a series of disparate local problems calling for solutions tailormade to suit local circumstances. Local authorities are empowered under the Act of designated casual trading areas and, where such areas are designated, it is an offence for a casual trader to trade elsewhere in the functional area of that local authority. By designating areas, local authorities can exercise control over caual traders in the location of the trading, in the number of permits they issue and through conditions attaching to the casual trading permits.

MainHeading.P: It is clear, therefore, that the onus is on local authorities to take the necessary steps to regulate casual trading in their own functional areas. In this regard, the Act is generally working satisfactorily. However, in view of the fact that the legislation has been in force for a decade and that some difficulties have arisen in its implementation, it was indicated in a response to Questions Nos. 53 and 56 on 5 December 1989 (Official Report, volume 394, columns 63 and 64) that, a review of the Causal Trading Act, 1980, would be undertaken. Any information which the Deputies may have on any particular difficulties being experienced by local authorities in relation to casual trading would be welcome in this regard and can be communicated to the Department of Industry and Commerce for consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prospecting Licences.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the townlands in County Mayo for which prospecting licences have been issued to date; the companies concerned in each case; the conditions and nature of the prospecting licence issued in each case; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Molloy) Robert Molloy
Speaker.P: The Minerals Development Acts, 1940 to 1979, provide for the granting of mineral prospecting licences which authorise the holders to enter upon the lands specified and there to carry out surveys or other investigations to ascertain whether mineral deposits of commercial interest exist there.

A condition attached to all licences is that the licensees must obtain planning permission in advance under the Local Government (Planning and Development) Acts 1963 and 1976 for any work contemplated under the licences which would require such permission.

Prospecting licences holders are also required to carry out their operations in conformity with good prospecting practices and not to interfere unnecessarily with the amenities of the locality in which the licence area is situated.

In cases where my Department is aware of an environmentally sensitive site e.g. an historic monument, detailed instructions are given to the licensee regarding their operations, otherwise they are required to consult the Office of Public Works or other relevant bodies.

There are at present 53 prospecting licences granted to 12 companies (Appendix A). The licences were issued for an initial term of two years subject to payment of the appropriate fee, and to the conditions generally applicable to the grant of prospecting licences. They were subsequently renewed for further periods, my Department being satisfied that sufficient prospecting work had been carried out and that acceptable work programmes would be undertaken.

There are several hundred townlands in the above licensed areas and the Deputy will appreciate that due to time constraints and staffing resources it is not possible to give a detailed list of the townlands in the reply.

Qst.Quest: if his Department officially recognise Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME) as a debilitating and a distressing illness, notwithstanding the difficulty in having the condition diagnosed; his views on whether most sufferers are unable to work by virtue of their condition; if he will discuss the matter with the Minister for Health to ensure that those sufferers, who qualify for disability or invalidity benefit, need not subject themselves to a total review of their welfare entitlements every six months, in view of the hardship accompanying such uncertainty; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: My Department recognises Myalgic Encephalomyelitis, or ME as it is commonly known, as a certifiable incapacity.As ME is a very difficult condition to diagnose, it can take some time before a person is finally diagnosed as having ME. In the intervening period, claimants are usually certified as being incapable of work from some other cause. As a result of this, perhaps, and also due to the relatively low incidence of the condition, my Department sees very little certification that actually specifies the cause of incapacity as ME.

All disability benefit and invalidity pension claims are subject to the normal medical evaluations provided by the Department's medical referees. In arriving at a conclusion on any particular case the referee has regard to all relevant evidence provided and in particular to comments submitted by the claimant's own general practitioner. In the instances in which a person is called before a medical referee his or her doctor is informed and invited to submit appropriate information in relation to the case. It is important to get as much information as possible from a person's own doctor in all instances, but particularly so in diagnosing conditions such as ME where the person's doctor can provide information on the nature of his/her patient's complaint over time.

I met representatives from the ME Association earlier this year. Senior officials concerned with the administrative and medical certification work in this general area were present. Arising from this meeting additional information on ME was distributed to the Department's doctors. As part of the Department's policy in keeping up to date with current medical issues a number of my Department's medical personnel recently attended a special session given by the Irish College of Occupational Medicine on the topic of ME. Also my Department's Medical Adviser attended the First World Symposium on ME held in Cambridge, UK, in April and a full report on these proceedings was issued to all medical referees.
The Minister for Health has to function in relation to certification for the purposes of sickness payment schemes under the Social Welfare Acts.

Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment assistance on 29 January 1990 and his claim was authorised for payment at the weekly rate of £88.90 on the basis of a nil means assessment previously made in his case. This rate is that appropriate in the case of a married person with two dependent children.

The person concerned has four children, but failed to supply supporting evidence in respect of two of them to the employment exchange. Qst.Quest: if, in view of the eligibility of married women to claim carer's allowance under the Social Welfare Act, 1990, he will clarify the amount of a husband's earnings which will be assessed as income in making a decision of an application.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The new carer's allowance will be introduced in October. It will replace the existing prescribed relative allowance.It is anticipated that an additional 6,000 people will be eligible for the new scheme bringing the total estimated number to almost 8,000. Under the new arrangements married women looking after an incapacitated pensioner will, for the first time, be able to claim the allowance.

In cases where the spouse of the carer is working the standard method of assessing income will be applied. The income of both the carer and spouse will be added together, and half of this assessed as the carer's means. The means as assessed will be deducted from the maximum rate of the allowance, £45 per week, plus increases for child dependants, if any, to determine the amount of allowance which will be paid.

Qst.Quest: if he will review the old age non-contributory pension case of a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: An appeals officer decided on 17 November 1989 that the person concerned was entitled to an old age non-contributory pension at the reduced rate of £22.50 per week from 19 May 1989 rising to £24 per week from 28 July 1989. He has been assessed with means derived from a holding.

The person concerned has transferred his holding to a nephew who has been resident in Scotland for many years. In these circumstances, the appeals officer has not accepted the transfer for old age pension purposes and the person concerned is still considered to be in beneficial occupation of the holding.

Under the terms of the Social Welfare Consolidation Act, 1981, a person may not deprive himself of pay, income or property in order to qualify for old age non-contributory pension. If it appears that a person has deprived himself or income or property in order to qualify for pension, the yearly value of that means or property is still taken to be part of the means of that person for the purposes of determining entitlement to old age non-contributory pension.

Following representations from the pensioner's solicitors, the case was reviewed in April 1990. As no new facts or fresh evidence were presented, the appeals officer's decision still stands. The decision of the appeals officer is final and conclusive and can only be reviewed in the light of new facts or evidence. If the circumstances of the person concerned have changed since April, he should advise my Department and his case will be reinvestigated.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he is considering the introduction of payments of assistance to students attending third level education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Assistance to students in third level education is provided mainly through the scheme of higher education grants administered by the Department of Education. As far as my Department are concerned I am anxious to ensure that unemployed people and particularly the long-term unemployed, are given every opportunity to participate in education courses. Opportunities for the long-term unemployed to avail of second level education courses without losing their unemployment payments are available through the vocational training opportunities scheme, originally the education opportunities scheme, which operates in 12 centres throughout the country and under which courses up to leaving certificate level are provided for long-term unemployed people over age 21. At present 170 people are catered for in the scheme. In addition I made regulations in 1989 under which long-term unemployed people can, under certain conditions, take up full-time second level educational courses while continuing to receive their unemployment payment.

I am also considering how the long-term unemployed can be enabled to take up courses at third level and I am making arrangements for a pilot scheme in this area to operate from the start of the next academic year.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the case of a person (details supplied) in County Kildare who is being denied payment for dental treatment as the dentist concerned refuses to lodge a claim with his Department; if he will outline the regulations governing the lodging of claims by dentists and patients; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There is no record in my Department of a recent dental benefit claim from the person concerned. Neither is there a record of a complaint from him regarding a dentist refusing to provide treatment under the scheme.

MainHeading.P: Under the social insurance dental benefit scheme a dentist, who is a member of my Department's dental panel, contracts to provide a certain range of dental treatment to qualified persons. Treatments such as examination, scaling, mild gum treatments and basic fillings are provided free of charge to the patient and the dentist is paid a fixed fee for these treatments by my Department. For certain other treatments, including root treatment and dentures, patients are required to pay a fixed amount to the dentists with the balance of the fee being met by my Department.

As part of a campaign of opposition to the extension of dental benefit to dependent spouses of insured persons some dentists are imposing charges for extractions, dentures and root canal treatment, which are not in accordance with the terms of their agreement with the Department. Discussions are taking place with the Irish Dental Association to find an agreed approach to the operation of the dental benefit scheme.

Any qualified person who is asked to pay inappropriate charges for treatment covered under the scheme, should refuse to do so and report the matter to my Department. However, there is no provision under the scheme whereby patients who proceed with treatment and pay such charges can be reimbursed.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the archival records, contained within his Department, which have been transferred to the National Archives; the records retained and the reason for their retention; if he will further indicate when those records not specifically retained will be transferred to the National Archives; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The National Archives Act, 1986, and the regulations made thereunder provide that departmental records which are more than 30 years old are due to be transferred to the National Archives not later than 1 January 1991.

Preparatory work is also in progress in relation to transfer to the National Archives of further departmental records which will be more than 30 years old on 31 December 1990. Records not transferred will be those in respect of which certificates may be issued under section 8 (4) of the National Archives Act, 1986.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the announcement regarding the recall of certain types of motor cars for safety reasons; if his Department have investigated whether these motor cars will be repaired or scrapped; the present position in relation to insurance cover; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the recent recall of a particular car model by one major distributor. In accordance with long standing practice, my Department's vehicle registration unit facilitated this recall, in the interest of public safety, by furnishing the distributor with a list of the present owners of the model affected from the computerised national vehicle file.

MainHeading.P: The recall of motor vehicles with design or manufacturing faults is solely the legal responsibility of the manufacturers and distributors. The Department have no function in relation to the terms of any recall notifications issued by manufacturers or distributors to owners of defective vehicles.

Where a vehicle owner is notified that a vehicle is defective, the owner is responsible for ensuring that the vehicle is repaired prior to being used on a public road or, alternatively, is scrapped and the licensing authority notified. The Garda Síochána is responsible for investigating a specific allegation that a defective vehicle is being used on a public road.

The compulsory motor insurance regulations provide that an insurer cannot refuse to pay compensation to an injured third party on the grounds that an insured vehicle which caused personal injury or property damage was defective.

Speaker.P: I am taking Questions Nos. 184 and 185 together.

MainHeading.P: The licensing of double-decker buses or coaches for long distance operation in the State is primarily a matter for the Garda Síochána under the Road Traffic (Public Service Vehicles) Regulations, 1963 to 1967.

The legal speed limit for a double-decker bus is 40 miles per hour. Private double-decker buses using public roads must have compulsory third party motor insurance. Buses owned by CIE, and its subsidiary companies, are exempt from compulsory insurance. CIE pay compensation to injured third parties from their own financial resources. Enforcement of the statutory requirements on speed limits and insurance is a function of the Garda Síochána.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recognition of Chiropractors.

Qst.Quest: if his Department intend giving recognition to chiropractors; if he has any policy to monitor chiropractors; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: There are two methods whereby professional disciplines are recognised by my Department. The first method is the establishment, by statute, of a registration body — as applies in the case of doctors, dentists, nurses, opticians and pharmacists. The second method involves the formal approval of qualifications by the Minister for Health under section 18 of the Health Act, 1970.

An important criterion for recognition is the employment of members of the profession concerned in the health services.Once that criterion is met, the most appropriate method for granting recognition can then be considered.

However, as chiropractors are not employed in the health services and as there are no proposals to so employ them, the question of recognising them by either of the mechanisms outlined does not arise.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the monitoring of chiropractors, as they are not employed in the health services, my Department have no function in this regard and I do not propose to introduce any measures which would change this position — either in regard to chiropractors or other practitioners of complementary and alternative medicine.

In regard to the position of chiropractors generally, I am aware that a therapy of this nature, falling under the general heading of complementary and alternative medicine, can be employed by those with a conventional training in health care as well as by people without any such mainstream training.

My Department maintain contact with a number of bodies representative of persons involved in complementary and alternative medicine and has suggested to them that an appropriate method of monitoring professional standards would be the development of systems of self-regulation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There is no specific provision in the higher education grants scheme relating to either adult or mature students. Also, there is no upper age limit in the scheme at present and it is, therefore, open to all students to sit the leaving certificate examination in the normal way for the purposes of qualifying for a grant on grounds of academic attainments and means.

MainHeading.P: Section 2 (1) (b) of the Local Authorities (Higher Education Grants) Act, 1968 allows Local Authorities who administer the scheme to award grants only to persons whose parents' or guardians' means are within the prescribed limit. There is no provision whereby adult students or students who may be independent of their parents may be means-tested without reference to their parents income.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Leaving Certificate Music Examination.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: her views on a report (details supplied) to the effect that a serious mistake was made in the questions put in the recent leaving certificate oral music examination; that music is marked unduly severely in the leaving certificate; and if she intends to take any steps to remedy the matter raised in the report in question.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I am aware of the report referred to by the Deputy.
The leaving certificate music examination consists of three components viz.
1. Practical or Project (100 marks) — held in March
2. Aural (130 marks) — held in May
3. Written (170 marks) — held in June
There is no oral examination in music.

Out of a total of 1,034 candidates who took the subject in the 1989 leaving certificate examination, 20 were awarded Grade A. In conjunction with the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment, I am examining the whole question of the relative grades awarded as between different subjects.

In the 1990 aural examination in music which took place in May, there was a minor error between information in question seven on the question paper and the corresponding piece of music on the tape. I am satisfied that this question, which related only to candidates taking the higher level paper, did not cause any undue problems for the candidates. However, it will be taken into account in the marking of the scripts of the candidates concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Archives.

Qst.Quest: if he will, in consultation with the National Archives, ensure that his Department maintain clear and comprehensive records of the current administration of Government business so that in time the transfer of such records to the National Archives will enable future generations to obtain an accurate and informed picture of the business of Government; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will outline the archival records, contained within his Department, which have been transferred to the National Archives; the records retained and the reason for their retention; if he will further indicate when those records not specifically retained will be transferred to the National Archives; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 279 and 282 together. I fully appreciate the importance, for archival and other purposes, of maintaining clear and comprehensive records of the administration of my Department's functions.

The transfer of records from my Department to the National Archives Office has not yet commenced. The work of identifying records for transfer and records for retention/disposal is well in hands however. As the Deputy will appreciate, this involves a significant amount of work, in view of the large volume of archival records held by my Department.

MainHeading.P: Detailed information on the National Archives Act, 1986, and instructions on action necessary to implement the provisions of the Act have been circulated to all staff of my Department. Certifying officers have been designated for overseeing the implementation of the Act.

An initial survey has been carried out aimed at identifying records which will be more than 30 years old on 1 January 1991 i.e. which come within the scope of the Act and which will require to be retained, disposed of, or transferred to the National Archives Office before 31 December 1990. Staff have been directed to expedite the work as much as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Air Freight Transport Services.

Qst.Quest: in view of Ireland's peripheral location and the growth in trade with EC and other countries, if he will outline the plans he has to develop efficient and cost-effective air freight transport services; and if such plans will necessitate the provision of additional storage, distribution and handling facilities at any Irish airports.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: In the National Development Plan submitted to the EC Commission in March 1989 the Government stated that it would seek Community support for commercially viable air and sea shuttle services between Ireland and Continental Europe. The Commission have agreed in the Community Support Framework that subject to the results of a feasibility study it would consider investment in such facilities.

MainHeading.P: This feasibility study, commissioned jointly by the Irish Government and the EC Commission, is presently being undertaken by SKC/CHL. I am not yet in a position to say what its findings will be or to indicate whether the type of facilities the Deputy refers to will be recommended. I have, however, made representations to the relevant EC Commissioners of the importance the Government attach to such shuttle services.

I would also like to point out that at the EC Council of Ministers meeting on 18-19 June, the Council on my initiative adopted principles on the liberalisation of air freight. When the opinion of the European Parliament has been received on these proposals formal adoption of the appropriate regulation will be considered by the Council. This regulation when adopted should significantly improve prospects for air freight services to/from Ireland.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Aer Lingus Subsidiary Losses.

Qst.Quest: in view of the opinions expressed at the Committee of Public Accounts recently, he will instruct departmental inspectors to investigate the circumstances behind the £10 million unreported losses by an Aer Lingus subsidiary; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: As I informed the House in reply to recent parliamentary questions in this matter, an accounting investigation into the reported discrepancies at Aer Lingus Holidays Limited was carried out by a major chartered accountancy firm, Craig Gardner, who furnished their report both to me and to the Board of Aer Lingus. As I have already indicated in my reply of 16 May last, that report has been referred to the Commissioner of the Garda Síochána for further investigation.

As the Deputy is aware, following receipt of the Craig Gardner report, I issued a number of instructions to the Board of Aer Lingus on 15 May, details of which were given in my reply of 16 May, and the chairman of the board has already confirmed to me that those instructions are being complied with.

All the appropriate measures necessary to ensure that this matter is thoroughly investigated have already been taken by me. Craig Gardner has fully investigated the matter; the report has been referred to the Garda and I have instructed the Board of Aer Lingus to take disciplinary and legal action where necessary. It would be unnecessary duplication to have departmental officials carry out a further investigation. I am satisfied that all the matters are therefore being fully investigated in the proper way.
